statement: B. Build the Permutationtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given three integers $$$n, a, b$$$. Determine if there exists a permutation $$$p_1, p_2, \\ldots, p_n$$$ of integers from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$, such that:There are exactly $$$a$$$ integers $$$i$$$ with $$$2 \\le i \\le n-1$$$ such that $$$p_{i-1} < p_i > p_{i+1}$$$ (in other words, there are exactly $$$a$$$ local maximums).There are exactly $$$b$$$ integers $$$i$$$ with $$$2 \\le i \\le n-1$$$ such that $$$p_{i-1} > p_i < p_{i+1}$$$ (in other words, there are exactly $$$b$$$ local minimums).If such permutations exist, find any such permutation.InputThe first line of the input contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10^4$$$) â€” the number of test cases. The description of test cases follows.The only line of each test case contains three integers $$$n$$$, $$$a$$$ and $$$b$$$ ($$$2 \\leq n \\leq 10^5$$$, $$$0 \\leq a,b \\leq n$$$).The sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases doesn't exceed $$$10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case, if there is no permutation with the requested properties, output $$$-1$$$.Otherwise, print the permutation that you are found. If there are several such permutations, you may print any of them.ExampleInput3 4 1 1 6 1 2 6 4 0Output1 3 2 4 4 2 3 1 5 6 -1NoteIn the first test case, one example of such permutations is $$$[1, 3, 2, 4]$$$. In it $$$p_1 < p_2 > p_3$$$, and $$$2$$$ is the only such index, and $$$p_2> p_3 < p_4$$$, and $$$3$$$ the only such index.One can show that there is no such permutation for the third test case.

You are given three integers $n$, $a$, and $b$.  Determine if there exists a permutation $p_1, p_2, ..., p_n$ of the integers from 1 to $n$ such that:

* There are exactly $a$ integers $i$ (where $2 \le i \le n-1$) such that $p_{i-1} < p_i > p_{i+1}$.
* There are exactly $b$ integers $i$ (where $2 \le i \le n-1$) such that $p_{i-1} > p_i < p_{i+1}$.

If such a permutation exists, find one. Otherwise, output -1.

You are given three numbers: n, a, and b.  

Determine if you can arrange n numbers from 1 to n in a specific order so that:

* There are exactly 'a' numbers where the number is bigger than the one before it and smaller than the one after it.
* There are exactly 'b' numbers where the number is smaller than the one before it and bigger than the one after it.

If such an arrangement is possible, show one example. If not, say "not possible".
